post.body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

body:
Are you sure about that? 6-7 hours is about the same timeframe most people can write a mildly complex algorithm, *in js* (even if it's not their main language!), and have it mostly working. Here are a few examples, note how the time between commits is only a few hours, even if they are long and/or complex:

https://github.com/Foxite/suguru (this commit in particular: https://github.com/Foxite/suguru/commit/07c8964f557a76cc47a10f43415655057e3e5111)

https://github.com/Foxite/picross

https://github.com/GingkathFox/esiJS

https://github.com/GingkathFox/EveShopper

https://github.com/GingkathFox/Node-Browser

And it also happens in languages other than JS:

https://github.com/Foxite/RepDecay

https://github.com/Foxite/ImageSetCompression

https://github.com/Foxite/YoutubeDL

https://github.com/Foxite/PatreonDownloader

https://github.com/Foxite/roosterbot

https://gitlab.com/foxite/someforum

https://github.com/justcool393/BotTerminator

https://github.com/justcool393/SnapshillBot

https://github.com/jakemayeux/pointandclick

I don't see anyone else taking 3-4 hours making a `for` loop through DOM elements work correctly.

body:
> How much time do you spend looking up other people's github projects?

Too much, but I'm looking for ways to try and improve. Unfortunately they seem to be doing things no differently than me!

I spent about 6 hours setting up 3 for loops for DOM elements. However I don't see how taking 7 hours to set up a very simple project is normal, seeing as it takes everyone else 1-4 hours for much more advanced projects (they're not exactly super complex, but in comparison to something that just hides ruqqus posts they're more advanced).

post.body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

parent.body:
Yeah I mean it's pretty hard to give an objective opinion on the matter without actually being physically present or seeing your work.

I think some people are bad at learning/understanding things, but if they get the right teacher, they are equally as capable as others are. Just an example of how it might not be as big of a deal as you think it is. 

Really though, I think it ultimately boils down to perspective. If I, at a high level of play, obtain no more fulfillment or satisfaction from playing league of legends than someone who is bad, why is it really that big of a deal for you to "suck" at things. I know that sucking at things makes you lose interest in them, but that what I mean about it being a perspective thing. I think to have interest in things has more factors than how do you are at it. Maybe consider "doing" less and learning more? In other words, rather than physical work, maybe think about doing more mentally oriented things?

How would you say your social skills are?

post.body:
I have a small problem where github is not letting anyone discover any of my repositories naturally. Most people I see get about 10-20 downloads per repo on average after a month or two, and get a small amount of traffic each day. This is typically done without any promotional efforts, so basically through the github algorithm and people discovering it through searching and exploring.

However, only one person other than me has ever downloaded something of mine, and according to the insights I'm getting absolutely *zero* traffic on any of my repos except for days I post about them on Ruqqus. This is not normal, so what could be the cause of it? Did github flag me as spam or something and suppress my repos from discovery channels? I did join less than a month ago and made a lot of contributions right off the bat, so maybe the servers think I'm a bot or something?

body:
> Your repo doesn't look complete, you're still adding and changing things.

Most of the repos I'm looking at are still on prereleases. [One got four stars and it doesn't even do anything yet](https://github.com/gingkathfox/ruqqjs).

> A game is OK, but a lot of times people are looking for tools, or libraries to build their own thing.

Most of the other people's repos aren't libraries. They're usually small apps that perform a very niche function. And only one of my repos is a game. It honestly feels like github is hiding me from potential traffic because it thinks I'm spam or something. Maybe since I have a very new account the systems don't trust me and it'll take a while for that to wear off, because I'm definitely not getting any views from github itself but other people are.

I also noticed that my repos are always further down in the search results than others' when searching for the same topic, for example: https://github.com/search?q=ruqqus

The repos from all the other major ruqqus contributors are on the first page, and mine is buried near the bottom of the second one. Maybe github suppresses me because I have a new account and will stop as time goes on.

It's not too big of a deal but it will hurt my ability to develop for a wide range of users.
body_html:
Your repo doesn't look complete, you're still adding and changing things.

Most of the repos I'm looking at are still on prereleases. One got four stars and it doesn't even do anything yet.

A game is OK, but a lot of times people are looking for tools, or libraries to build their own thing.

Most of the other people's repos aren't libraries. They're usually small apps that perform a very niche function. And only one of my repos is a game. It honestly feels like github is hiding me from potential traffic because it thinks I'm spam or something. Maybe since I have a very new account the systems don't trust me and it'll take a while for that to wear off, because I'm definitely not getting any views from github itself but other people are.

I also noticed that my repos are always further down in the search results than others' when searching for the same topic, for example: https://github.com/search?q=ruqqus

The repos from all the other major ruqqus contributors are on the first page, and mine is buried near the bottom of the second one. Maybe github suppresses me because I have a new account and will stop as time goes on.

It's not too big of a deal but it will hurt my ability to develop for a wide range of users.

## Posting Rules


Rule 1: 

This guild is for shitposting about people/events in the Ruqqus Discord server. Any post that is not related to this will be kicked to +general. If you need help regarding the discord server, +askruqqus, +general, or +hub would gladly accept your questions.


Rule 2:

No spamming. Spamming would be considered any of the following:

* Same-format posting within a day

* Same-content posting within a day (Same content, different format)

Rule 3: 

No reposts: reposts are cringe. Any reposts will be kicked.

Anyone know why the discord users are doing this?

I doubt it. For example ruqqus-plus is behind even ruqqyou and it's a much larger project that probably gets quite a bit of attention (from ruqqus, it's not lucky enough to be visible from github itself). But ruqqJS is a 3-commit project that doesn't even do anything yet and was placed at the very top immediately. I would say the download count and views and stars and such are the *consequence* of where it appears in search, not the cause.

Looking at the history of the repos, it looks like where it appears in the search results has more to do with who you are than anything else. I've noticed that the same people always get the same patterns of traffic and positions in search results for all their repos. How this is determined I have no idea, but it seems like that's how it's working. On reddit, I made the front page a few times and after that all my posts were always more visible than before and reaching the front page was easier. Then I changed accounts and it became harder again. I wouldn't doubt that github is doing something similar.

post.body:
I have a small problem where github is not letting anyone discover any of my repositories naturally. Most people I see get about 10-20 downloads per repo on average after a month or two, and get a small amount of traffic each day. This is typically done without any promotional efforts, so basically through the github algorithm and people discovering it through searching and exploring.

However, only one person other than me has ever downloaded something of mine, and according to the insights I'm getting absolutely *zero* traffic on any of my repos except for days I post about them on Ruqqus. This is not normal, so what could be the cause of it? Did github flag me as spam or something and suppress my repos from discovery channels? I did join less than a month ago and made a lot of contributions right off the bat, so maybe the servers think I'm a bot or something?
